State of Michigan
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RICK SNYDER NICK LYON
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 10, 2018
Debra Matthews, President
Children’s Center Wayne County
79 West Alexandrine
Detroit, MI 48201
RE: License #: CB820201055
Children's Center Wayne Co
79 W Alexandrine
Detroit, MI 48202
Dear Ms. Matthews:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on June 6,
2018. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Implementation Sustainability and Exit Plan (ISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3012
Enclosure
George Winn, COO
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child's record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in R
400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(a) All of the following child characteristics:
(iii) Height and weight.
One out of eight case records reviewed did not include the height and weight on the
child’s record within 7 calendar days after placement.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM RENEWAL 2017
Two out of eight case records reviewed contained late updated service plans. The
first case record was late with one service plan by two days. The second case
record was late with one service plan by fourteen days.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS
MiSACWIS
(Commitment
22)
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (MiSACWIS) which will be the
4

primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
Fifteen out of thirty - seven case records reviewed from foster care, licensing,
adoption and independent living; documentation of reports and required forms were
observed in the children case records, however the agency was not consistent in
uploading the information into MiSACWIS.
The information that were not consistently uploaded were Family Team minute
meetings, service plans with signatures on the PATP, initial placement outlines,
updated medical passports, permanency goal review for PPFWR and APPLA,
medical and dentals and child adoption assessments.
ISEP 6.18 Page Relative Foster Parent Licensing, Timeliness
23 - 6.18
(Commitment
54)
DHHS must license at least 85% of newly licensed relative
foster parents within 180 days of the date of placement.
The agency has 03 relatives in the process of licensing that extend beyond 180
days. Patterns of lateness include receiving DHHS investigations, criminal history
verification, timely submission of paperwork, psychiatric/medical report and relative
motivation.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS
MiSACWIS
(Commitment
22)
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (MiSACWIS) which will be the
primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
5

The agency was informed that all required paperwork needed to be uploaded into
MiSACWIS on a consistent basis for all programs.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were three incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period and all three foster home/foster parents were recommended for
revocation of their license. The first foster home the agency cited the foster parent’s
for foster parent qualifications and medical and dental care. The second foster
home the agency cited the foster parent’s for foster parent qualifications and
unusual incident notification. The third foster home the agency cited foster parent
qualifications, behavior management, medical and dental care and substitute care;
agency notification. The agency’s handling of the special evaluations were
appropriate. The agency found all three foster parent’s to be unsuitable to meet the
needs of the children placed in their homes.
There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period to include one foster parent using a plastic bat to hit the child for discipline
and in the second foster home the foster parent was whipping the child for discipline.
The agency cited both foster homes for behavior management and discussing and
re-signing the agency’s behavior management/discipline policy. The foster parent’s
corrective action plan included reviewing and signing the agency’s behavior
management/discipline policy with the assigned worker. The agency’s handling of
the special evaluations appears appropriate.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a corrective action plan for the 04/28/2017 renewal inspection
report. It affectively addressed the following non-compliances:
400.12310 (2) Initial evaluation, 400.12319 (d) Substitute care policy, 400.12319 (e)
Substitute care policy, 400.12327 (1) Special evaluation, 400.12327 (1d) Special
evaluation, 400.12405 (4) Change of placement, 400.12418 (2a) and (2b)
Development of service plans, 400.12421(d) Visitation and parenting time,
400.12605 (1) Adoption family evaluation, ISEP 6.33 (c) Assessments and service
plans, content, DHHS policies FOM 722.03B, 722 -06I, and FOM 722- 08C. The
agency overall did well this inspection as they only have repeat citations late initial
and updated service plans and MiSACWIS entries.
The 03/07/2018 analyst report was reviewed and follow up to concerns are as
follows:
Concern: During a visit to a relative provider home, the analyst observed a
blanket tucked in the sides of a crib. A critical alert was sent to the agency
6

Resolution: The agency asked the relative to remove the blanket. The relative
complied and a picture was taken of the crib without the blanket. The relative
also signed an agreement not to place the blanket on the bed again. The critical
alert with the picture and agreement has been placed on DCWL’s S drive for
review if needed.
Concern: A foster home was using a loft bedroom that required a variance in
order to meet requirements for bedroom walls that have permanently attached
walls that run from floor to ceiling.
Resolution: The foster home was given an approved variance for the foster
home for the duration of the foster home license. It was dated 07/31/2015. A
copy of the variance is kept in the agency file obtained by the licensing consultant.
Concern: Foster parent reported that the foster home licensing process was
taking too long.
Resolution: A review of the case record for this foster home was reviewed. It
was noted that the barriers for this foster home was obtaining paperwork timely
from the foster parent along with their criminal background check.
Concern: Foster parent reported not seen, discussed, or signed a Medical
Passport and did not recognize the sample shown by the Analyst.
Resolution: Upon review of the case record, the foster parent signed four
service plans and two medical passports. The agency received a citation for not
having the information uploaded into MiSACWIS.
Concern: One birth parent reported that referrals are not being made in a
timely manner.
Resolution: Upon review of the case record and interview with the
social service worker, forms were given to the social service worker to present
to the child’s therapist. The therapist was out of the office for several weeks
and when she returned, the child started seeing the therapist. All other
referrals were completed in regards to the parent and children.
7

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the Children’s Center of
Wayne Co. continue on a regular license.
Pinkey Brown Date 07/10/2018
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 12, 2018
________________________________________
Linda D. Tansil Date
Area Manager
8
